snippet: Dinosaur fossils are often found with sharply curved necks, but research challenges the assumption that the position indicates an animal died in the throes of agony.
abstract: Achim G Reisdorf study in journal Palaeobiodiversity and Palaeoenvironments suggests that dinosaur fossils are often found with their necks bent back at an extreme angle because of the natural effect that water exerts on a corpse, and not because they died in agony as previously assumed.
lead_paragraph: Dinosaur fossils are often found with sharply curved necks, but research challenges the assumption that the position indicates an animal died in the throes of agony.

headline.seo: Archaeopteryx Fossils Appear Twisted, but Not Because of Agony
headline.main: No Animals Were Harmed in the Making of This Fossil
headline.print_headline: No Animals Were Harmed in the Making of This Fossil
